pageTitle: Carpenter hired as UTA senior associate vice president, chief communications officer
shortDescription: The University of Texas at Arlington has appointed Joe Carpenter as senior associate vice president and chief communications officer for the Departmen
body:
The University of Texas at Arlington has appointed Joe Carpenter as senior associate vice president and chief communications officer for the Department of Institutional Advancement. Carpenter currently serves as vice president for university relations and chief communications officer at Radford University.

At UTA, Carpenter will work closely with the vice president of institutional advancement, Dee Robinson, President Vistasp M. Karbhari and the senior leadership team to lead the University’s global marketing and communication efforts, institutional marketing and brand positioning, internal communication, media relations and community outreach. Carpenter, a successful leader and manager, has received accolades for helping transform Radford University and elevate the university’s positioning. He led Radford University’s strategic and analytics-based marketing plan and fostered a culture of customer service, teamwork and collaboration. He contributed to historic fundraising efforts and record-setting undergraduate applications.

“Joe has led diverse and highly complex organizations in developing and executing strategic communication, crisis communication, reputation management, marketing, media and government relations,” Robinson said. “His experience with issues and leadership across large organizations and crises will elevate UTA’s reputation and provide an even greater catalyst for research, academic and economic change throughout our region.”

Prior to Radford, Carpenter served a career in the U.S. Navy, retiring at the rank of commander. His many Navy public affairs assignments included director of congressional information and public affairs for the Secretary of the Navy’s Office of Legislative Affairs in Washington, D.C. and as the director of public relations and chief communications officer at the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., previously ranked as U.S. News & World Report’s No. 1 public college.

“I am excited to be joining the institutional advancement team at this special time for the University of Texas at Arlington,” Carpenter said. “UTA has a growing reputation as being the model 21st-century urban research university that is setting the standard for higher education and making real impacts in our communities and in industry. I am looking forward to collaboratively promoting a greater awareness of the success of our students, the excellent teaching and innovative research of our faculty, the dedication of our hard-working staff and diverse accomplishments and successes of our alumni.”

Carpenter earned a bachelor’s degree at the U.S. Naval Academy and a master’s degree at the U.S. Naval War College. His first day will be Aug. 20.

pageTitle: Beware of ProCard scams
shortDescription: The Office of Procurement Services has been made aware of potential scams and attempts at fraud.If you receive a call about money owed for a product,
body:
The Office of Procurement Services has been made aware of potential scams and attempts at fraud.

If you receive a call about money owed for a product, validate that you have received the product and have the invoice in hand before giving the person your ProCard number. Ensuring both measures are taken will help reduce the risk that your card will be compromised. 

Payment Card Services reminds cardholders that if your ProCard appears to have been compromised, lost, or stolen, please report it immediately. The process to report is as follows:

  • Immediately contact the UTA Police Department at 817‐272‐3381 and file a police report.
  • Once you have a police report number, contact CitiBank at 800‐248‐4553. CitiBank representatives are available 24 hours a day, seven days a week to assist you.
  • You must email Payment Card Services at paymentcard@uta.edu or call 817-272‐2194 once you have completed the first two steps. Provide the UTA Police report number in all communications.

A new card will be issued within five to seven business days and sent directly to Payment Card Services, which will contact you as soon as the card is available for pick up.

If you have any questions, please contact Payment Card Services at paymentcard@uta.edu or by calling 817-272‐2194.

pageTitle: Don't fall for telephone scams
shortDescription: Be cautious of phone callers who demand money by gift cards or online transfers, the UTA Police Department advises. These scams often increase near th
body:
Be cautious of phone callers who demand money by gift cards or online transfers, the UTA Police Department advises. These scams often increase near the beginning of the new semester or when tuition payments or fees are due.

If someone calls you and demands immediate payment for an alleged debt by gift card, MoneyGram, or any other transfer of funds:

  1. Ask for the caller's name, employer, and phone number.
  2. Hang up. Check the company's or agency's phone number online. Call that number to verify that the caller is from a legitimate company or government agency.
  3. Call the UTA Police Department at 817-272-3381 if you feel that the caller is a fraud and file a report.
  4. Do not give personal information over the phone, such as a Social Security number or a bank account routing number.
  5. Do not make any payments to a company or government agency over the phone unless you are able to verify the call. If in doubt, call the UTA Police for assistance.

body:
Pat Taylor, retired landscape architecture faculty member, died Sept. 8.

Dr. Taylor was a highly respected scholar and faculty member in the landscape architecture program. He came to UTA in 1992 as director of the program, having earned his B.S. and M.S. degrees from Texas Tech University in park administration/landscape architecture and Ph.D. from UT Austin in organizational studies. He retired in 2016.

He was executive director of the Council of Educators of Landscape Architecture and a Fellow of the American Society of Landscape Architects.

pageTitle: Office security tips
shortDescription: Limit the possibility of office burglaries by following these office security tips from the UTA Police Department:  Always lock your office door when
body:
Limit the possibility of office burglaries by following these office security tips from the UTA Police Department:  

  • Always lock your office door when leaving your workspace.
  • Don’t leave valuables (laptop, purse, cellphone) unattended in an unlocked office, meeting room, or other unsecured area. 
  • Report non-functioning lights, broken doors or windows, and malfunctioning locks immediately.
  • Pay attention to people who don’t belong in your work area. Engage them by asking if they need assistance.
  • Report suspicious persons or activity to UTA Police immediately.

pageTitle: UTA Police warn against scams
shortDescription: The UTA Police Department urges everyone to be vigilant against scams. Here are a couple of the methods these scammers use to take advantage of their
body:
The UTA Police Department urges everyone to be vigilant against scams. Here are a couple of the methods these scammers use to take advantage of their victims: 

  • An email promising a job opportunity if you go to a website link. The email appears to be from the Job Placement and Student Services office. But there isn’t any office by that name on campus. The scammers will want to transfer a check to your account with a large sum of money, but that's only because they want access to your bank account. If something seems too good to be true, it probably is.
  • A phone caller demands immediate payment for a debt (taxes, student fees, etc.) and threatens arrest or other action. The caller wants the payment through a gift or money card. Remember that legitimate government agencies won’t demand immediate payment through gift cards, money cards, or other alternative means. If you receive a call like this, hang up and confirm the agency’s legitimacy. Don’t provide any money or personal information over the phone in these circumstances. 

Spread the word about these scams.  By looking out for each other, we can help keep our community safe.

pageTitle: Save by turning off electrical devices
shortDescription: A few actions on your part can help conserve energy on campus during the winter break. The Office of Facilities Management suggests these steps to rea
body:
A few actions on your part can help conserve energy on campus during the winter break. The Office of Facilities Management suggests these steps to realize maximum energy savings:

• Turn off and unplug electrical devices. Many devices remain in standby mode or use power even when turned off, including computers, monitors, scanners, printers, copiers, chargers, power supplies, appliances, and other electrical devices. If items are plugged into power strips, simply turn off the power strips.

• Lower the heating temperature and turn off air conditioning. Areas controlled directly by an occupant should have the air conditioning and fans turned off. Heating and air conditioning in many campus buildings are controlled by a computerized energy management system that will set these areas to maximize energy conservation during the break.

• Turn off all lights when you leave. Parking lot lighting schedules have been adjusted where feasible, taking campus safety and security into consideration.

pageTitle: Clean up now to prevent post-holiday surprises
shortDescription: The Office of Facilities Management suggests cleaning break rooms before the winter break.• Wipe down and clean out break rooms or common areas of any
body:
The Office of Facilities Management suggests cleaning break rooms before the winter break.

• Wipe down and clean out break rooms or common areas of any food items or candy to keep from attracting insects.

• Empty the refrigerator and turn off the ice maker. 

• Remove all perishable items from the refrigerator and freezer. Check all expiration dates and dispose if expired.

• Clean the inside of the refrigerator. Wipe down the drawers, shelves, sides, and floor of the fridge. Dry thoroughly.

• Place baking soda, a bowl of dried oats, or a shallow bowl of dry, fresh coffee grounds and crumbled newspaper inside the refrigerator to combat mildew, mold, and bad odor. When you return, remove newspapers and oats/coffee grounds and wipe down the drawers and sides.

The meters are designed for short-term parking, allowing customers a place to quickly park and run into a facility to handle brief business. The meters are $3.75 for 30 minutes and 90 minutes and $2.50 for three hours. See the map.

For customers wanting long-term metered parking, the Maverick Garage and West Parking Garage offer an all-day rate of $11.

The old coin-only meters will be replaced with a combination of pay-by-app-only meters or pay stations. The MobileNOW app is free. There are existing credit card meters that will remain and still accept coins and credit cards. Bills eventually will only be accepted in garages.

The new signage is planned to better communicate with customers about the meter rates, maximum times, and payment methods so they can make the best decisions for their parking sessions.

Parking permit holders—faculty, staff, and students—must pay at metered parking spaces.

For more parking information, go to the Parking and Transportation Services website at uta.edu/pats.

pageTitle: UTA's police dispatchers vital to campus safety
shortDescription: Join the UTA Police in recognizing the department's dispatchers during Public Safety Telecommunicators Week, April 14-20.Public safety telecommunicato
body:
Join the UTA Police in recognizing the department's dispatchers during Public Safety Telecommunicators Week, April 14-20.

Public safety telecommunicators, or dispatchers, are vital to the police department’s ability to serve the University community. Our dispatchers and communications supervisor ensure the staffing of UTA Police's Communications Center 24 hours a day, seven days a week to consistently monitor vital systems and provide a professional line of communication with our community.

The UTA Police Communications Center answers and processes approximately 8,000 emergency and non-emergency calls for service each month. Dispatchers coordinate the response of police and public safety officers, manage approximately 2,100 queries into the FBI criminal justice information system, monitor fire and burglar alarms, assist with the monitoring of cameras across the UTA campus, and provide valuable information to students, faculty, staff, and visitors to the UTA campus.

pageTitle: in Memoriam: David Leong
shortDescription: David Leong, assistant to the dean for information technologies for the College of Business, passed away Oct. 18.He came to UTA in 1982 and earned his
body:
David Leong, assistant to the dean for information technologies for the College of Business, passed away Oct. 18.

He came to UTA in 1982 and earned his master's of business administration degree in 1986. While a student, he worked as a graduate assistant and became a full-time employee. He was named to his last position in 1997. 

Leong focused on instructional technology and other aspects of the College of Business building, classroom furniture, safety and security systems ,and technology infrastructure.

Donations may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.

Memorial services are pending.

body:

pageTitle: Parking Appeals Committee needs applicants
shortDescription: The Parking Appeals Committee needs applicants for 2019. The committee adjudicates student, faculty, staff, and visitor citation appeals.Applicants mu
body:
The Parking Appeals Committee needs applicants for 2019. The committee adjudicates student, faculty, staff, and visitor citation appeals.

Applicants must be in good standing with Parking and Transportation Services. This means that they can’t owe a balance to the University and must not have had a citation within the past six months.

Each appeals committee is made up of three officers who make the final decision on a customer’s citation appeal. Applicants must be available to hear committee appeals for a minimum of one hour per month. Compensation will be a complimentary one-day parking pass for the Maverick Parking Garage for each day they hear an appeal.

If interested, complete the application form and you will be contacted to schedule the information and training session.

pageTitle: Steam service outage planned
shortDescription: The Thermal Energy Plant has planned its annual outage of campus steam service to complete inspection and repair requirements of system components. Th
body:
The Thermal Energy Plant has planned its annual outage of campus steam service to complete inspection and repair requirements of system components. The outage is scheduled to begin at midnight Monday, May 20. Normal operations should resume by 10 p.m. Saturday, May 25.

During that time, the buildings served by the Thermal Energy Plant will be without hot water and steam, including heated water for the swimming pools. Electrical power, air conditioning, and chilled water services will still be available.

pageTitle: Allowance for cheaper alternative airfare
shortDescription: The Office of Disbursements strives to enhance the travel procedures for improved efficiencies and business practices for all University travelers. Fo
body:
The Office of Disbursements strives to enhance the travel procedures for improved efficiencies and business practices for all University travelers. 

For trips originating Wednesday, May 1, 2019, and afterwards, there will be a new review process for travelers who find airfare at a savings of $100 or more outside of Corporate Travel Planners (CTP), Anthony Travel Inc. (ATI), or CONCUR.

The alternative airfare will be reviewed. Submit an exception prior to the trip to the Business Affairs Exception Tracker. Required documentation will be:

  • Alternate Airfare Request Form—Form BF-T-F9
  • An email from CTP or ATI confirming their inability to price match.

This is not allowed for federally funded travel seeking discounted airfare on a foreign carrier, per the Fly America Act.

For complete information, please see Procedure BF-T-PR8.

pageTitle: Driving personal vehicles for University business
shortDescription: UTA employees are discouraged from using their personal vehicles to conduct official University business. When the employees do this, their personal a
body:
UTA employees are discouraged from using their personal vehicles to conduct official University business. When the employees do this, their personal auto insurances will be primary at all times.

The UT System “Hired/Non-Owned” insurance policy provides liability-only coverage for an employee using his or her personal vehicle while conducting official University business. The coverage is secondary to the employee's personal auto insurance, used only for property damage or bodily injury to third parties, and does not provide any coverage for physical damages sustained to the employee's vehicle.

Additionally, an employee involved in an accident while driving a University-owned vehicle may be responsible for the vehicle and may be personally liable for the entire loss if the University vehicle was used by an unauthorized individual, for an unauthorized purpose, or in an unauthorized manner.

Questions? Refer to the UTA Driving Records/Training Procedure, Section VI, or contact the Environmental Health & Safety Office at 817-272-2185 or ehsafety@uta.edu.

body:

The Follett Discover online platform is available for faculty to renew textbook orders or browse new textbooks for their courses. Textbook orders also can be hand-delivered to the UTA Bookstore or submitted via email to the course materials manager at 0812txt@follett.com.

pageTitle: Register for accessible parking permit
shortDescription: Parking and Transportation Services (PATS) has begun an enforcement campaign to reduce abuse of the handicap parking stalls on campus and to ensure on
body:
Parking and Transportation Services (PATS) has begun an enforcement campaign to reduce abuse of the handicap parking stalls on campus and to ensure only Department of Motor Vehicles-approved customers utilize the accessible parking stalls.

UTA requires disabled veterans and persons with disabilities (PwD) to register their license plates with the PATS office to help reduce abuse of the spaces. Once registered, disabled veterans will receive a complimentary Disabled Veteran–General Student or Disabled Veteran–General Faculty/Staff permit. PwD customers must purchase an ADA–Faculty/Staff or ADA–Student permit to use the accessible parking stalls.

Customers with an unverified placard or plate may receive a $250 citation that asks for owner information. Once the owner information is supplied and verified with DMV records, the citation will be reduced and an e-ADA or e-DV permit will be issued. The citation will remain $250 for customers who do not supply ownership information.

Please be proactive and submit ownership information by emailing parking@uta.edu.

Read more about accessible parking options.

pageTitle: Year-End Deadline for Requisitions Over $15,000
shortDescription: Submission of requisitions for 2018-19 purchases of $15,000 or more are due Friday, July 12.Requisitions must be fully approved and successfully budge
body:

shortDescription: Innovative, dynamic, and creative college professors are invited to use their experience and knowledge to lead summer courses offered through UTA's TR
body:
Innovative, dynamic, and creative college professors are invited to use their experience and knowledge to lead summer courses offered through UTA's TRIO Pre-College Programs. Upward Bound and Upward Bound Math and Science programs offer high school students the opportunity to participate in a six-week residential program at UTA every summer.

UTA's TRIO Pre-College Programs have provided college preparation services to low-income/first-generation students since 1982. The U.S. Department of Education recently renewed funding for the next five years for programs at UTA.

If you are a college professor who wants to use your expertise to make a difference in young people’s lives, then consider applying to be an Upward Bound or Upward Bound Math and Science instructor. 

Apply online for Upward Bound or Upward Bound Math and Science.

If you have any questions or need additional information, please contact the TRIO Pre-College Programs at 817-272-2610.

pageTitle: Book marks 100 years of 'The Shorthorn'
shortDescription: Celebrate 100 years of The Shorthorn, UTA's student newspaper, with a commemorative coffee table-style book. Inside the large-format book are 100 hist
body:
Celebrate 100 years of The Shorthorn, UTA's student newspaper, with a commemorative coffee table-style book. Inside the large-format book are 100 historic front pages documenting the transformation of UTA from Grubbs Vocational College in 1919 to the incredible campus we know today.

Through Wednesday, July 3, faculty, staff, and departments can purchase a copy for $30 each. The book retail price is $40.

Consider purchasing a copy for guests to read in your department’s lobby, for someone who enjoys history, for yourself, or simply to support The Shorthorn.

Payment can be made via IDT for department purchases, or by cash, check, or credit card for personal purchases.

Contact the Department of Student Publications at 817-272-3188, email book@shorthorn.uta.edu, or visit the office at Suite B100 of the University Center.

pageTitle: Law enforcement exercises on campus
shortDescription: Law enforcement personnel, teenagers, and young adults will conduct various real-life crime scenarios and role-playing exercises on campus this week a
body:
Law enforcement personnel, teenagers, and young adults will conduct various real-life crime scenarios and role-playing exercises on campus this week as part of a program aimed at youth interested in careers in law enforcement.

More than 400 law enforcement officers and youth will be on campus Thursday-Sunday, July 18-21, for the Texas Law Enforcement Explorer Advisors Association 2019 State Explorer Competition. The annual event features teams of youths and adults competing in various real-life law-enforcement scenarios.

The exercises will take place in a variety of locations on campus, including parking lots, classroom buildings, the University Center, and residence halls. All events will be on the east side of campus.

Some of the scenarios and exercises will include simulated active shooters, bomb threats, gang activity, robberies, domestic crises, minor traffic stops, and more.

Individual competitions include a bicycle obstacle course and a physical agility course at The Green at College Park and a non-emergency vehicle obstacle course at lots 50, 51, and 53. A car show is planned for the University Center mall.

For questions related to the Explorer competition, visit tleeaa.org.

In addition, a video shoot for the UTA Police Department is scheduled for Saturday morning at the Science & Engineering Innovation & Research Building. Public access to the building will be closed, and signs will be posted to alert people to the video production.

For questions related to the UTA PD video shoot, contact Captain Mike McCord at mccord@uta.edu.
